image.altText: outside of a courthouse in the sun

items.synopsis: An Indigenous mother who spent 10 years in indefinite detention will walk free after the Northern Territory government lost a Supreme Court appeal to have her remain in custody, arguing she is a "serious risk" to the public.

title.children: Darwin mother released from indefinite detention after government loses appeal

image.altText: Erica Vlasic in her living room.

items.synopsis: Erika Vlasic received two reports about a home she wanted to buy. She said one came back with "no big issues", the other found the property was suited to "demolition".

title.children: When Erika offered $700k for a home, she didn't know it was 'better suited to demolition'

image.altText: A placid blue lake surrounded by green forest

title.children: A 'golden spike' in Canada could mark the beginning of the Anthropocene Epoch

title.children: How Christianity has been weaponised by weight loss movements

image.altText: A young white woman with glasses sits at a desk in front of a laptop.

items.synopsis: Australians targeted by the illegal robodebt income averaging scheme are considering their legal options after the damning royal commission report suggested there was evidence to support a further civil case.

title.children: Robodebt report provides avenue for further civil action and compensation for victims

image.altText: A dead crocodile is laid out onto a table with its mouth being held open by a man

items.synopsis: The saltwater crocodile involved in an attack at Wangi Falls in the Northern Territory has been killed, while the 67-year-old victim remains in hospital in Darwin.

title.children: Crocodile shot and killed after man hospitalised in attack at Top End waterhole

title.children: Tennis's comeback queen stuns world number one Iga Swiatek to be one match from Wimbledon final

image.altText: Ava the dog is standing attentively on a rug and sniffing Donna's head, while Donna hugs Ava and laughs.

items.synopsis: For two decades, Donna has travelled confidently around the world and through Sydney with the support of various guide dogs. So what happens when one suddenly passes away?

title.children: 'I felt my safety was out of my control': Donna's world was turned upside down when her beloved guide dog died

image.altText: Russia U.N. Ambassador Vassily Nebenzia with his hand raised to veto extension

items.synopsis: A long-running humanitarian program delivering aid to 4 million people in Syria could be closed as Russia fights against its extension at the UN.

title.children: 'Act of utter cruelty': Fears for Syrian aid after Russia vetoes renewal

image.altText: Man wearing navy uniform

items.synopsis: The Russian military official was shot dead by an unknown assassin while on his morning run after appearing on a Ukrainian blacklist website.

title.children: 'Liquidated': Russian commander on Ukraine's blacklist shot dead on run

image.altText: ce patterns settle on a car roof in Donnybrook, Western Australia

items.synopsis: If you live in a frost-prone region you are likely familiar with the mosaic-like branches and spirals that stretch across windows and cars on an ice-cold morning. But how does Mother Nature create the magnificent display?

title.children: This isn't art. It's ice, sculpted by Mother Nature

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Wall Street rose boosted by energy stocks on higher oil prices, and Treasurer Jim Chalmers says his recommendation for next RBA governor will go to cabinet for approval. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US stocks gain ahead of inflation report, Treasurer says RBA appointment will go to cabinet for approval

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has open higher after a rise on Wall Street. The ASX 200 index is up 0.6 per cent in the first 10 minutes of trade. Most sectors have increased with energy stocks leading the way after oil prices jumped overnight as the greenback fell, on hopes of higher demand, and production cuts by major producers. Data centres operator Megaport (+5.3 per cent) is doing the best, while Bellevue Gold (-3.3 per cent) has given up some of this week's gains.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market has open higher after a rise on Wall Street.
The ASX 200 index is up 0.6 per cent in the first 10 minutes of trade.
Most sectors have increased with energy stocks leading the way after oil prices jumped overnight as the greenback fell, on hopes of higher demand, and production cuts by major producers.
Data centres operator Megaport (+5.3 per cent) is doing the best, while Bellevue Gold (-3.3 per cent)
has given up some of this week's gains.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The House of Representatives economics committee is grilling ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott on branch closures. Mr Elliott says ANZ had 678 branches in 2017 and now has 391 branches. Most of the 287 closures have been in major cities. Mr Elliott says ANZ now has 250 branches in major cities, 75 branches in inner regional areas, 47 branches in outer regional and 19 branches in remote or very remote areas. He says 96 per cent of transactions are done online, with only 8 per cent of customers using branches because they don't do any digital banking at all. "Most of them are actually, they're more likely to be small business operators," Mr Elliott told the committee." "Small businesses have more complex needs than individuals." "So retail customers generally pretty well service on a on a digital basis."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 287 ANZ branches closed since 2017

children.content: The House of Representatives economics committee is grilling ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott on branch closures.
Mr Elliott says ANZ had 678 branches in 2017 and now has 391 branches.
Most of the 287 closures have been in major cities.
Mr Elliott says ANZ now has 250 branches in major cities, 75 branches in inner regional areas, 47 branches in outer regional and 19 branches in remote or very remote areas.
He says 96 per cent of transactions are done online, with only 8 per cent of customers using branches because they don't do any digital banking at all.
"Most of them are actually, they're more likely to be small business operators," Mr Elliott told the committee."
"Small businesses have more complex needs than individuals."
"So retail customers generally pretty well service on a on a digital basis."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott is giving evidence to the House of Representatives economics committee. He says loan arrears remain low despite interest rates rising steeply to 4.1 per cent over the past year. "Only $6 of every $1,000 in our Australian home loan portfolio was overdue by more than 90 days. "That is better than it was before the pandemic." Mr Elliott says ANZ customers are "faring extremely well" and people are still saving, although the bank has seen a modest increase in customers "reaching out to us for help". "So people are actually in remarkably good shape," he says. "Now, there are clearly those that are struggling, but it's a relatively modest amount." "If I look at things like the calls we get coming into our call centres in asking for help. " "Those are up a little bit." "And if we look back over time, is still lower than they would have been prior to COVID."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ says loan arrears remain low

children.content: ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott
is giving evidence to the House of Representatives economics committee.
He says
loan arrears
remain low despite interest rates rising steeply to 4.1 per cent over the past year.
"Only $6 of every $1,000 in our Australian home loan portfolio was overdue by more than 90 days.
"That is better than it was before the pandemic."
Mr Elliott says ANZ
customers are "faring extremely well"
and people are still saving, although the bank has seen a modest increase in customers "reaching out to us for help".
"So people are actually in remarkably good shape," he says.
"Now, there are clearly those that are struggling, but it's a relatively modest amount."
"If I look at things like the calls we get coming into our call centres in asking for help. "
"Those are up a little bit."
"And if we look back over time, is still lower than they would have been prior to COVID."

image.altText: Thumbnail Simon Crisp Marrawah murder.

items.synopsis: Simon Crisp was putting the rubbish out after his partner's shift at a remote country pub in north-west Tasmania when he was shot three times. Ten years on, Tasmania Police are renewing efforts to find his killer.

items.synopsis: A second young person claims to have received abusive messages from the BBC presenter accused of paying a teenager for sexually explicit images, while BBC insists on keeping him anonymous.

title.children: BBC presenter sent threatening messages to second young person
